awd_abstract_narration:
The award supports research in algebraic geometry, a central branch of mathematics which aims to understand, both practically and conceptually, solutions of systems of polynomial equations in many variables. Algebraic geometry has important applications to other fields of mathematics, such as number theory, topology, and analysis, as well as to physics, biology, cryptography, and engineering. Young researchers including graduate students will be involved in this project.

The PI will work on a variety of topics centered around degenerations of algebraic varieties and functorial, geometrically meaningful compactifications of their moduli spaces. The central part of the project is the study of functorial compactifications of moduli spaces of K-trivial varieties, such as K3 surfaces, hyperkahler varieties, Calabi-Yau varieties, and abelian varieties, including both explicit descriptions of these compactifications, as well as their properties such as Kodaira dimension and canonical models. A separate project is on the volumes of log surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A moduli space is a mathematical device encompassing all objects of a particular type, such as curves, surfaces, bundles, algebras, etc. They are ubiquitous in all fields of mathematics and in physics. Most naturally occurring moduli spaces are not compact, and a major problem is to find geometric compactifications for them; both to study their numerical properties, and to understand degenerations of the objects, as parameters go to infinity.

One of the most famous compactifications in algebraic geometry (also used in number theory, topology, analysis etc.) is the Deligne-Mumford's moduli space of stable curves. Recently, this theory was extended to higher dimensions, and the resulting compactification are known as KSBA spaces, after Kollár, Shepherd-Barron and Alexeev.

The main activity of this project was to study one of the most important and intriguing cases, that of K3 surfaces (so called by André Weil after a formidable K2 mountain). The project resulted in several advances, both theoretical: a major result showing that these compactifications can be described and studied by methods of fans in toric geometry, and practical: very explicit descriptions of these compactifications in concrete cases.

The results were published or are to appear in leading journals, such as Annals of Mathematics, Crelle's Journal, Transactions of American Mathematical Society.

The grant also contributed to the development of graduate students and a postdoc.
